Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Developing a Continuous Reconstruction of Tropical Pacific Climate Over the Last 500-700 Years: Analysis of Massive Porites Corals from American Samoa
Award.AbstractNarration:
Records of baseline ocean-atmosphere variability provide critical context for understanding changes in mean climate state. However, ocean?atmosphere variability is not well understood during the time between the anomalous Medieval Warm Period/Little Ice Age and the present (the last ~500-800 years). This project-- a collaboration between Columbia University's Lamont Doherty Earth Observatory and Stanford University-- will develop a proxy record of variability in the western tropical Pacific over the past 500+ years. Coral cores collected from giant Porites colonies in Ta'u Island, American Samoa, will be analyzed for interannual- to centennial-scale variability in temperature and salinity (Sr/Ca and oxygen isotopes), indicating changes in the extent of the South Pacific Convergence Zone.

The researchers will partner with the National Park of American Samoa to construct an exhibit illustrating the use of long coral cores to study environmental change. This exhibit, displayed at the park's information center, will include Ta'u coral core material and data associated with this study. The project will support a post-doctoral researcher at Lamont and a graduate student at Stanford.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on generating near-monthly resolution records of past climate change using long Porites lutea coral cores that had been previously collected from the Island of Ta’u in American Samoa. We also analyzed several shorter coral cores collected from the nearby island of Ofu. Our work under this award was based entirely in laboratories at Stanford and Columbia universities.

Prior to this award, we collected cores from an exceptionally large Porites coral colony in American Samoa. Corals grow about 1 to 2 cm per year and their carbonate skeletons contain a variety of chemical signals that can be used to reconstruct a number of features related to local climates back through time. The advantage of this method is that it can be near-instrumental in quality and can provide information about changes in water temperatures and salinity extending back far before measurements were made directly using thermometers or conductivity sensors. In this case, we are interested in the past history of El Nino as well as a climate system component responsible for rainfall over a large portion of the Pacific basin, the South Pacific Convergence Zone (SPCZ). This American Samoa coral provided an opportunity to reconstruct South Pacific climate from a location in the center of the SPCZ over the last 400-500 years. By analyzing this coral core we sought to learn more about: 1) the relationship between decadal climate variance and El Nino variability, and 2) how the SPCZ position has varied over the last 400-500 years. Thus influencing rainfall and storm tracks throughout the South Pacific. We also sought to answer the questions: Is there a clear anthropogenic climate change signal visible in the American Samoa region?

X-rays of the coral core reveal continuous growth between the late 1490’s and 2011 AD (the year we collected the cores). A long isotopic record shows a significant long period trend with the lowest d18O values generally concentrated in the most recent portion of the record. If interpreted solely as a change in SST the data indicates long-term warming of up to 3°C at this site. However, we now know that the Ta’u coral record reflects a mixture of both sea surface temperature and salinity change. It also contains an interesting record of El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) and South Pacific Convergence Zone (SPCZ) variability.

Similar to Linsley’s previous coral records developed from Fiji and Tonga, annual variations in sea surface temperature dominate the annual coral isotopic cycle while interannual changes are influenced to a larger degree by salinity variability.  Over the last ~30 years there has been a close relationship between SPCZ movements and El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) with the SPCZ shifting northeast during El Niño events and southwest during La Niña events. This SPCZ re-positioning results in more saline conditions on average in the Samoa region during El Niño as the SPCZ shifts NE and the westward flowing South Equatorial Current (SEC) advects relatively salty water into the region. Our results show that this relationship between SPCZ position and El Niño events existed back until 1927. Prior to 1927, the Ta’u coral d18O record contains distinct evidence that on average there were fresher conditions during El Niño events in Samoa/American Samoa. This is evidence of a more southwesterly mean position of the SPCZ prior to 1927 when an abrupt regime change in the SPCZ response to El Niño events occurred.
